fields.description:
For larger groups avatars are not always recognizable so the ability to see author names directly would be useful.

Also the #files affected in a change set would also be useful as part of the description. This is part of the (i) info popup, but popups (2 click + mouse movement)are cumbersome when simply trying to view the scope and size of the changesets.
fields.summary: CommitGraph  Add option to show author name and # of changed/add/deleted files

but clicking through to change set or activity it does show the proper avatar for the author.

Avatar settings
https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/
r=pg&d=identicon
fields.summary: When using gravatar's Commit Graph doesn't show avatar

fields.description:
It would be cool if review -author- {color: green}any participant{color} could exclude from review sections of a single file similarly as you can exclude files right now.

I'm not sure at the moment which would be more useful:
- excluding any range of lines 
- excluding sections that were discovered by diff algorithm

{color: green}_pstefaniak edited on Wed 19_{color}
fields.summary: Ability to remove selected file "chunks" from review

fields.description:
In the JIRA fisheye plugin, there is a configuration option to determine what sort of Fecru instance the plugin is linked to.  The way the setting is worded is very confusing.

!fecru setting.png!
What this means is:
 - Yes = Fisheye and Crucible
 - No = Fisheye only
 - Standalone = Crucible only

We do have this documented, but this is very confusing for the customer - we should change the text!  Would be even better if we could detect automatically.
fields.summary: JIRA fisheye plugin configuration is confusing

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1) Create 2 FE repositories and 1 CRU project
2) Associate both repos with 1 CRU project
3) Create reviews to both repositories
4) Delete one repo
5) Browse existing reviews.

Result: The ones from removed repository are shown in UI but cause exceptions.
Expected result alternatives: 
a) Reviews are deleted
b) reviews are rematched to same source files if other related repositories contain same changesets
c) <your proposal here>
fields.summary: Exception when review source repository has been deleted

fields.description:
In FishEye Search (both the standard search and the EyeQL search) it would be quite useful if the "Moved from" and "Moved to" fields could be shown (optionally) in the search result.

This information is present in the database, because if you drill down to a particular revision, and show its details, you can see the Moved from or Moved to fields. It would be nice if these could be added to the "return clauses" of the search.
fields.summary: Show "Moved from" and "Moved to" information in results of FishEye Search

fields.description: When adding new SVN repo using wizard, on page 3 of 3 there is a checkbox "Store Diff Info" selected by default. Apparently even if I untick that and finish wizard, the "store diff info" option remains enabled. To verify just navigate to new repo configuration, select "SCM Details" tab and you can see the box is selected there.
fields.summary: when adding new repository, the "Store Diff Info" option is ignored

fields.description: Under certain circumstances diff text files are not being deleted
fields.summary: DiffTextCache files not deleted

fields.description:
There are several issues logged about handling branches and moves better. One of the things that may be a way around this is to make it so the indexing threads can index changes past the large branch (assuming they are not in that branch).

We have some projects that do a lot of branching and it can take up over 8 hours for that branch scan to be completed. Meanwhile there are other changes going on in other branches that devs need to see in order to make a post commit code review. The face that they have to wait over 8 hours for a commit to show up can severely affect their productivity.
fields.summary: Make it possible to parallel index changes from the same repo.

fields.description: When the current branch head is removed from a repository (by whatever means), FishEye's attempt to use that commit as the first commit in the a..b style commit argument fails.
fields.summary: Handle case where the current branch head commit is removed

When testing the connection for a Mercurial repository, the test fails if the initial clone takes more than 60s. It is still possible to add the repository and have it indexed without errors but the fact that it failed the test is a bit misleading. Perhaps a clearer message of what is being done could help avoid any "alarms" about this.

2012-12-06 11:09:40,764 DEBUG [btpool0-853 ection-1354788520720] fisheye.app LoggingProcessMonitor-onAfterFinished - Finished process: /home/admhg/mercurial/2.1.1/bin/hg --config ui.verbose=false clone --noupdate -r 0 https://acme.com/~bbunny/carrots/ /home/admfish/fisheye_inst/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1354788520721  took 60031ms
2012-12-06 11:09:40,765 INFO  [btpool0-853 ection-1354788520720] fisheye.app LoggingProcessMonitor-onAfterFinished - Exception executing command "/home/admhg/mercurial/2.1.1/bin/hg --config ui.verbose=false clone --noupdate -r 0 https://acme.com/~bbunny/carrots/ /home/admfish/fisheye_inst/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1354788520721 " process timed out

{noformat}

fields.description:
Limiting Fisheye content in a Crucible project does not:

- Have any effect on the Activity Stream
- Have any effect on statistics in a project view 
- Prevent a user from adding data outside the included repositories

Reindexing the repository or Crucible data doesn't seem to have any effect.

To reproduce:

1. Create a new repository in Fisheye.
2. Associate said repository with a Crucible project.
3. Under {{Projects -> Fisheye Content ->}} add a new path for the repository content.  For example, only include {{/tags}}.
4. View the Project URL (http://<host>:8060/project/<project_key>)

You will observe that the project isn't restricting the Activity Streams or statistics based on the path provided, it will still include all activity from the FE repository.
fields.summary: Restricting Fisheye content  to repositories path in Projects is not reflected in Activity Stream and Statistics

fields.description:
{quote}
Before 2.9.0, our development workflow would go like this:

- Developer commits code to Subversion and marks Jira issue as fixed (issue is assigned to nominated code reviewer).
- Code reviewer creates a Crucible review by pressing "Create crucible review for all 2 changesets" on the Source tab in Jira.
- Code reviewer finds issues that need fixing and makes appropriate comments in crucible review
- Code reviewer rejects Jira issue back to developer
- Developer makes appropriate changes, commits code to Subversion and marks Jira issue as fixed.
- Code reviewer adds content to the existing Crucible review by pressing "Create crucible review for all 3 changesets" on the Source tab in Jira.

This last step no longer works since the suggested reviews were removed in 2.9.0. This has a big impact for us because there is no easy way to add new changesets to an existing review. We can add them manually in Crucible, but there is a high chance that we'll miss some, especially when the review spans multiple repositories.

How can we restore this critical feature?
{quote}

{quote}
I had no particular love for the suggested reviews feature most of the time - the only good part was to update the existing review from Jira.

I like the idea of the "update review with changesets" link in Jira. We normally only have one Crucible review per Jira issue, but I guess you could provide the user a selection list of the active reviews if there ever is more than one.
{quote}
fields.summary: Re-introduce a way to add new revisions to an existing review from JIRA

fields.description:
When you are using JIRA for authentication and you make a user 'inactive' in JIRA, they are still displayed in Fisheye and appear to be active and counting against license limits.

Making a user inactive in JIRA should make them inactive in any application using JIRA for authentication.

Jordan Dea-Mattson

fields.description:

fields.description:
Nick Pellow wrote an awesome EAC documentation on folder layout in FECRU:
https://extranet.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=2038794163

We should update out existing documentation here:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+folder+layout

On second thought we should really merge the docs. What are your thoughts?
fields.summary: Updating Fisheye folder layout documentation

fields.description: Add a step to increase the open file limit https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=137265407 in the documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Installing+FishEye+on+Linux+and+Mac
fields.summary: Update on 'Installing FishEye on Linux and Mac' documentation

fields.description:
When FishEye get into 'Too many open files' error, the error fill up the logs non-stop until the harddrive is full and the system is down.

All FishEye functions should be stopped so that it will not generate the error in the log and FishEye should show the error in the UI and the steps to fix it.

Related article for customers who hit the error on the workaround: https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=137265407
fields.summary: Stop All FishEye function with the error 'Too many open files'

fields.description:
To reproduce the problem:
# Login to a FishEye/Crucible instance with more than 1000 users (and Oracle database).
# Go to {{People > All Users}}.
# Select the "Reviews" column heading to sort by the number of reviews.

From [JRA-19317|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-19317]:
{quote}
Oracle will not permit more than 1000 literals in an {{IN}} clause. It does, however, permit {{SELECT}} statements in the {{IN}} clause which can return an unlimited number of elements.
{quote}

The following exception can be found in the logs:

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Fresh install of FECRU 2.9
2. Add a repo with a few commits (less than 50 to see the problem quickly)
3. In a web browser, navigate to the cross-repo activity stream (http://localhost:8060/changelog)
4. Scroll down the activity stream

Expected result:
Once the earliest commit is reached, no more activity will be shown, and you will see the message 'No previous activity found.' (this is what happens when you view the activity stream for an individual repo)

Actual result:
Once the earliest commit is reached, the commits continue to be displayed but this time in the reverse order. If you keep moving further down the stream, the activity stream will bounce again once it reaches the latest commit. The stream thus appears never-ending, but is actually just repeating itself (see screenshot)
fields.summary: the cross -repo activity stream repeats activity when the end is reached

fields.description: The documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+Indexing does not mention about the effect of decreasing the indexing threads. When the threads is decreased, the threads will not stop any scanning currently occurring. To get the effect immediately due to performance issue, a server restart will be needed.
fields.summary: Update on Configuring Indexing documentation

fields.description: {{ChangesetCommentIndexer}} loads all changeset comments for a given rep into memory. This will not scale with large numbers of changeset comments. Implement a paging approach.
fields.summary: Changeset comment re-indexing loads all cs comments at once

fields.description:
{{DefaultChangesetCommentManager.getCommentsForRep()}} uses {{HibernateUtil.session()}} to access comments. This means that a threadlocal session is created on the indexing thread, which will never be closed. More-over, comments loaded into the session will remain in memory. 

If for example a customer has 1000 repos, and each repo had 1000 changeset comments, at the end of a reindex of all 1000 repos, there will be 1,000,000 changeset comment objects held in the session associated with the indexing thread.

In addition, you'll get those "Waiting for session to close" messages on shutdown.
fields.summary: Changeset Comment re-indexing incorrectly uses a threadlocal session.

fields.description: When checking source files in a repository, it would be nice to have "Ignore End of Line Characters" when diff-ing files the same way the "Hide All Whitespace" option is implemented. fields.description:
The CVS indexing code does its own thing for update polling, and that includes configuration. There are two user-configurable settings:

1. history file location ( defaults to {{CVSROOT/history}}
2. full scan period (defaults to 15 minutes)

"full scan period" determines how often the entire RCS file tree is stat'ed to check for changes. Setting this to 0 disables full scans, in which case only history file checks are performed on ping.

A third, non-configurable setting is the "poll period" - the rate of pings. For CVS, this is currently hardwired to 5 seconds.

A customer wishes to control CVS slurp, by fully disabling interval-based ping, and calling {{fisheyectl scannow}} instead (via a commit hook). This is currently only possible via an ugly work-around.
fields.summary: [CVS] Allow pollPeriod to be configurable
test

Update JIRA Crucible Sub-Task configuration instructions
Improve the way permissions are handled, as a lot of time is spent in user/repo permission checks, which should be cached

fields.description:
When restoring an OnDemand FishEye backup into a BTF FishEye 2.8.0 installation, in {{config.xml}}, the {{driver}} and the {{driverSource}} attributes in the {{<connection>}} element were removed. These attributes contain correct data derived from the OnDemand instance if the customer chooses to use PostgreSQL as the database for their BTF installation. When the imported FishEye was started using this {{config.xml}}, it complained that the JDBC driver was not found.

My expectation is that these 2 attributes should be retained if other command line options indicate that the customer is using PostgreSQL as database. Further discussions about the scenario can be found here: https://sdog.jira.com/wiki/display/FCBM/FECRU+Backup+Requirements?focusedCommentId=61931646#comment-61931646

These are the steps I followed:
# Decompress a {{fisheye-2.8.0.zip}}
# Prepare a PostgreSQL database for the FishEye installation:
{noformat}
zxu@zxu-desktop:~/tmp/20121107083444$ sudo su - postgres
postgres@zxu-desktop:~$ psql 
psql (9.1.5)
Type "help" for help.

postgres=# create database crucible_new ENCODING 'UTF-8' OWNER fisheye;
CREATE DATABASE
postgres=# grant all on database crucible_new to fisheye;
GRANT
postgres=#
{noformat}
# Import the OnDemand backup using the following command line:
{noformat}
fecru-2.8.0/bin/fisheyectl.sh restore --username fisheye --password fisheye --jdbcurl jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/crucible_new --dbtype postgresql --file ./FeCru-backup-20121105.zip
{noformat}
# Compare the {{config.xml}} from the OnDemand export and the one living in BTF FishEye, and notice the following differences:
{noformat}
<         <connection driver="org.postgresql.Driver" jdbcurl="jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/fisheye" username="fisheye" password="eK4dUPIB9a" driverSource="bundled"/>
---
>         <connection jdbcurl="jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/crucible_new" username="fisheye" password="fisheye"/>
{noformat}
# Try to start the FishEye instance but it does not start, complaining missing JDBC driver.

Here are the relevant files / logs:
* OnDemand export file: [^FeCru-backup-20121105.zip]
* The output from the restoration command: [^restore.out]
* {{config.xml}} post restoration: [^config.xml.post-import]
* BTF FishEye log: [^fisheye.out]
fields.summary: "fisheyectl.sh restore" removes some database connection attributes

fields.description:
Customers reported issues where they struggled to restore Fisheye backups.  Although backups seems correct, when they run restore command it fails with error like:
{code}
#
# A fatal error has been detected by the Java Runtime Environment:
#
#  SIGBUS (0x7) at pc=0x00007fd4cffb7a82, pid=25426, tid=140552036337408
#
# JRE version: 7.0_07-b10
# Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (23.3-b01 mixed mode linux-amd64 compressed oops)
# Problematic frame:
# C  [libzip.so+0x4a82]  newEntry+0x62
#
{code}

Even when disableMemoryMapping property is set to avoid SIGBUS error
{code}
FISHEYE_OPTS="-Dsun.zip.disableMemoryMapping=true " restore -f ...
{code}
(further details: http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/core-libs-dev/2010-February/003636.html http://cr.openjdk.java.net/~sherman/6929479/webrev/ )

the restore still fails.

It seems the issue is caused by having osgi cache being included in the backup file.  There is no point of including this cache, as felix would easily recreate this cache on startup.
fields.summary: OSGI cache should be excluded from backup

;-)

fields.description:
The "Polling Interval" values are not consistent between what is allowed and the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Updater]. In fact, as long as a digit is included as the first character, any string following it is allowed.

From the documentation:
{quote}
Polling Interval — Specify how often FishEye will check to see if there have been any new commits to the repository. Use the following terms to specify particular units of time: s, m, h, d, w, mo, y (for seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months and years respectively). For example, 10s. The default value for this field is 60 seconds.
{quote}

To reproduce:
# Go to {{Administration > Repository Settings > Repositories}}.
# Select a repository by clicking on its name.
# Select "Updates".
# Unselect the "Use the system default settings for updates" box.
# Write anything as long as it starts with a digit. Example: 0monkeys
# Hit "Save".
fields.summary: "Polling Interval" Does Not Validate Allowed Values Properly

fields.description:
The "Operation Timeout" values are not consistent between what is allowed and the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Perforce].

Taking for example what is stated in the "P4 Operation Timeout":
{quote}
Sets the timeout value that FishEye imposes on P4 operations. Operations which exceed this value are terminated. The default for most operations is 10 minutes. 
Use the following terms to specify particular units of time: s, m, h, d, w, mo, y (for seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months and years respectively). For example, 10s.
{quote}

This is allowed:
{noformat}
(s|second|seconds|mi|minute|minutes|h|hour|hours|d|day|days|w|week|weeks|mo|month|months|y|year|years)
{noformat}
Meaning that "m" can't be used and "mi" should be used instead. Also the error message is not indicative of what can be used:
{quote}
Operation timeout value is not a valid time interval. Examples of time intervals: "25 seconds", "5 minutes", "2 hours", "2 days"
{quote}

This is valid for all repository types.

To reproduce:
# Go to {{Administration > Repository Settings > Repositories}}.
# Select a repository by clicking on its name.
# Select "SCM Details".
# Write "1m" in "Svn Operation Timeout", "Command Timeout" or "P4 Operation Timeout".
# Hit "Save".
fields.summary: Inconsistency Between Allowed Values For "Operation Timeout" and Documentation

fields.summary: Upgrade tasks are not run for CVS repositories

fields.description:
The documentation [Backing Up and Restoring FishEye Data|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Backing+Up+and+Restoring+FishEye+Data] didn't mentioned that restoring backup from older version (ex. 2.7.13) to a newer version database (ex. from 2.8.2) connected to a FishEye 2.7.13 is considered as a downgrade and it is not supported.

Please update the documentation and mentioned that we shouldn't restore the older version backup to a newer version database even though the FishEye server running has the same older version.
fields.summary: Update on Backing Up and Restoring FishEye Data documentation

fields.description: Jira and Confluence have adequate LDAP support for user authentication. It seems as if fisheye is not using this implementation. In particular, the option to do an incremental sync is missing. It is unclear why fisheye has other requirements than jira and confluence, such that a different implementation is necessary; there seem to be only disadvantages.
fields.summary: Fisheye LDAP  should provide same features as jira and confluence.

fields.description:
SVNKit 1.7.6 introduced couple fixes that were affecting FishEye users:
 * http://issues.tmatesoft.com/issue/SVNKIT-319 Too many svnserve processes in case of svn+ssh connection
When FishEye tries to index svn repositories over svn+ssh protocol, it creates far too many Java threads inside FishEye JVM and also spawns the same amount of svnserve processes on the subversion repository server.
 * http://issues.tmatesoft.com/issue/SVNKIT-316 Diff always displays absolute paths instead of relative on Windows (even URL-URL diff)

Fisheye in 2.7.x releases use SVNKit 1.3.3, and Fisheye 2.8.x releases use SVNKit 1.7.4.  

h4.Workaround
Switch to [Native Subversion Client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Native+Subversion+Client] with the latest SVNKit version (1.7.6+).
fields.summary: SVNKit upgrade 1.7.4v1 to 1.7.6

fields.description:
If a git repository has include or exclude paths specified, then GitScanner.shouldIndexChangeSet will return false if a commit only affects paths which are out of scope.  This will mean that we don't actually store that changeset.

If changesets aren't indexed and they end up having children which should be indexed, then the logs will be filled with messages like this:
{code}
    [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,584 WARN  - Parent not found: commit a460b4bc23a1974bbb58078c8a6bd2aef3441dca, parent 8826cc85a0ef6b50c9082bbb83ae78c35b6afd08
     [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,615 WARN  - Parent not found: commit e2859024dbca6325660dea2e69c5a1a61ba055c7, parent a460b4bc23a1974bbb58078c8a6bd2aef3441dca
     [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,666 WARN  - Could not determine position of earliest parent for changeset e2859024dbca6325660dea2e69c5a1a61ba055c7; earliestParent == null
     [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,715 WARN  - Cannot resolve changeset parent id a460b4bc23a1974bbb58078c8a6bd2aef3441dca for changeset e2859024dbca6325660dea2e69c5a1a61ba055c7
     [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,887 WARN  - Could not determine position of earliest parent for changeset 78fdb1a230626f4a6881e65aa58c47d4c52eddc9; earliestParent == null
     [java] 2012-10-19 14:59:24,955 WARN  - Cannot resolve changeset parent id a460b4bc23a1974bbb58078c8a6bd2aef3441dca for changeset e2859024dbca6325660
{code}

To reproduce the issue, I've attached a sample git repo.  The issue can be reproduced by adding the "/branches" directory as an include path.

We need to determine how much of a problem this actually is - if these errors are not a problem in this case then we should maybe be logging them as DEBUG.  More likely I think we always need to create a changeset object.
fields.summary: Fisheye may miss change sets when you use include/exclude paths with git.

fields.description:
We would like to be able to known who is logged in, or when was the last time a list or a particular user on fisheye/crucible logged on. 

Is there any way to do that? or through a plugin?
fields.summary: capture or reporting on user events like logout/logoff/last logged in.

fields.description:
Based on 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/User+Management+Limitations+and+Recommendations

It says the optimal number of users that the jira server can handle is 500 from another application using it for as the user directory source. 

What are the limitations or the behavior of jira if you have more than 500 users.. 

Basically Fisheye does not come with embedded crowd like Jira/Stash/confluence, I am finding that maintaining the security groups for developers access to Project/Source Repository increasing difficult and painstaking to be able to see at the glance. 

As we increase our user base that is allowed to connect to fisheye and creating 500+ repositories, it is getting harder to troubleshoot the correct access through the ldap filtering.

We are not considering stand-alone crowd at this time, so that is not my solution. I have a current need to keep the products separated as well in that respect. Ideally it would be nice for a future version of fisheye to have embedded crowd to match the rest of the atlassian products.
fields.summary: If Jira is used as User Directory for Fisheye and we have over 500 users. What exactly are the implicated limitations from the documentation.

fields.description:
Seems to be a regression of an issue fixed in the past, see FE-727.  Same steps to reproduce:
1) Navigate to https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/browse/FE/trunk/test/testfiles/simple or to some directory within your repository 
2) In the Tarball box, click on zip and download the zip
3) Double click on zip file and you will get the error "The Compressed (zipped) Folder is invalid or corrupted"

Apparently FishEye is serving zipped file which gets gzipped by Jetty filter and MSIE8 (and MSIE7 but not MSIE9) struggle to open or save this file properly. See http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2002350 

This issue is fixed in recent Jetty versions: http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/JETTY-1409 .  

In the meantime we can change the Content-Type header so MSIE8 would be able to cope with it.
fields.summary: "The Compressed (zipped) Folder is invalid or corrupted" error in IE8 when downloading tarball from "Download Archive" link

fields.description:
Would be nice to have a report for LOC filtering the counts for specific users and excluding certain subdirectories or regular expression matches.

For example we don’t want our “blah” user in the numbers and we want to exclude a 3rd party directory structure in our SVN repo.

fields.description:
The Object Management Group's Interface Definition Language (IDL) is a language used for defining interfaces used by CORBA implementations to communicate with each other.  It'd be nice if syntax highlighting for this language was implemented.  Here's some documentation:
[http://www.omg.org/gettingstarted/omg_idl.htm]

The PDF found here has the actual language specification in it: [http://www.omg.org/cgi-bin/doc?mars/2011-09-08]
fields.summary: Add custom syntax highlighter for OMG IDL files

fields.description:
With a lot of repositories in FishEye/Crucible, logs don't allow to be easily tracked per a specific repository (in case if we have issue with one of them and need to troubleshoot). Instead, all repositories are logged as one "stream". Following log files are generated:
* fisheye-debug-(date).log
* fisheye-error-(date).log
* fisheye-mail-(date).log

The idea is about adding _fisheye-debug-*(repositoryName)*-(date).log_. It would be MUCH easier to read only those which are selected by the *(repositoryName)*. Via extending log4j configuration adding such extra logger is quite trivial feature to implement.
fields.summary: Split log by repositories

fields.description:
This feature does not seem to be listed from:
http://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fisheye.html

FishEye user is trying to develop a system to integrate with fisheye and would like to pull the source code using the REST API provided by Fisheye.

For example if he can view the source code with the url: 

fisheye.host.com/browse/demo/demo.cs?hb=true, it should be possible to get the full source code text using the REST API if they have this url and login info
fields.summary: Retrieving Source Code From Fisheye Using REST API

I'm not sure since which version is this broken, but some customers reported this problem in v2.8.2.

fields.description:
Currently FishEye/Crucible OnDemand only support the built-in Subversion repository.
This is a serious limitation in the OnDemand version and isn't obvious from the Atlassian website (we only discovered this post-purchase assuming it would be near feature parity with the download version).
*Fisheye/Crucible OnDemand should support at least BitBucket and GitHub* especially since JIRA OnDemand does.
fields.summary: OnDemand support for Git on BitBucket

fields.description:
Hi There.

A customer is reporting the following:

{quote}When hovering over a users avatar an error occurs when using IE8. We have verified that it works as expected using FF or Chrome. In IE9 I don't see the error, but the information never loads.{quote}

I was able to reproduce this behavior in FishEye/Crucible 2.8.1 using IE 8 and IE 9 - In Firefox it worked normally. I also tried on a FishEye/Crucible 2.7.15 but it worked correctly.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*

I assume this is a new bug.
fields.summary: Avatar's Hover Error

fields.description:
On this page: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Migrating+to+SQL+Server

In the "Configuring and Migrating via the Command Line" section, in the actual command, there needs to be double quotes around the jdbcurl command, like

--jdbcurl "jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://hostname:port;databaseName=dbName;" \

Currently those quotes are missing. When the command is missing, it gives an error about how "username" is an unknown argument.

Also, to actually complete the command, a --force must be added. The logs at least tell you this.
fields.summary: Command Line database migration command missing double quotes

fields.description:
Not every fisheye/crucible user with admin to fisheye/crucible has login privileges to the server host (especially Windows). The Fisheye/Crucible admin UI does provide a nice interface for initiating a support request that automatically packages the support.zip, but if a followup support.zip dump is required the only way to get the support zip file is to ask the server administrator to get the file for the user to attach to the existing support request.
Please provide a "download support.zip" interface in the Fisheye/Crucible admin UI to facilitate simpler retrieval of support.zip file.
fields.summary: Download interface for support.zip file

fields.description:
FishEye does not correctly handle the section output from Subversion property diffs.

The impact of this is that FishEye can not correctly determine if a file is binary or not, and ends up trying to index it's diff-text.

* in SVN 1.7, the format of property diffs changed from a +/- to a full unified diff.
* we should not bother processing property diffs, we should just note there is a change and then load the property value fully from subversion
* can we get the property from SVN in a more efficient way. Maybe getting the property in BULK when we get the paths ?
* what we are doing now, is actually incorrect.
* we should consider and test the performance implications of this.
** test with a remote SVN server
** when a merge occurs, there are many property changes
** what impact is getting all these property changes going to have on performance?
** we could potentially ignore this property?
* IF THERE IS NO FAST AND RIGHT WAY, WE SHOULD NOT DO THIS FOR THIS RELEASE.
* Check with @Richard Stephens
* Its not easy to reproduce this behaviour, though Richard has a recipe and needs to update this ticket.
fields.summary: FishEye is not correctly handling svn 1.7 property diffs (which are in unified format)

fields.description:
Hi there.

A customer is experiencing a weird situation, he is adding 2 different Repositories with different names (but simmilar).

I was able to reproduce the behavior:

# Create two subversion repository one as 'ABC-123' and another as 'ABC123'
# Now add the first repository in Fisheye by clicking on 'Add Existing' and give the Name of the repository as  'ABC-123' and location as that of SVN repository 'ABC-123'.(I am assuming that you have SVN and FeCru on the same server and you are using 'file' protocol to give the location of the repository in fisheye repo addition)
# Now you must be able to access the just added repository (ABC-123)
# Now add the second repository in Fisheye by clicking on 'Add Existing' and give the Name of the repository as  'ABC123' and location as that of SVN repository 'ABC123'.
# Once you add the second repository, you will see that there are two repository entry in fisheye with name 'ABC-123' and both are pointing to svn repository 'ABC-123'. No entry will be found in fisheye for 'ABC123'.
# However, you will get entries for both the repository in config.xml

In the UI it shows 2 identical repositories like the image below:

!Duplicated Repo.jpg|thumbnail!

In the {{FISHEYE_INST/config.xml}} the information is right:

{code:xml}
<repository name="ABC-123" description="" store-diff="true" enabled="true"><svn url="file:///opt/repositories/svn/ABC-123" path=""><symbolic auto-rules="true"/></svn>
      <security use-defaults="true" allow-anon="false" allow-logged-in="false" allow-anon-write="false" allow-logged-in-write="false"><required-groups/><required-write-groups/></security>
</repository>

<repository name="ABC123" description="" store-diff="true" enabled="false"><svn url="file:///opt/repositories/svn/ABC123" path=""><symbolic auto-rules="true"/></svn>
      <security use-defaults="true" allow-anon="false" allow-logged-in="false" allow-anon-write="false" allow-logged-in-write="false"><required-groups/><required-write-groups/></security>
{code}

*PS:* I tried with the {{file://}} protocol, with the Repositories located on the same host then FishEye and also using {{http}} protocol, with the Repositories located on another server.

If I try to delete one of the repositories (ABC-123) using the {{UI}} FishEye gives this {{ERROR}}:

{noformat}
Error calling server:com.google.gwt.user.client.rpc.StatusCodeException: 500 The call failed on the server; see server log for details Unknown.K9b(Unknown Source) Unknown.ucc(Unknown Source) Unknown.ZBb(Unknown Source) Unknown.BCb(Unknown Source) Unknown.anonymous(Unknown Source) Unknown.Awb(Unknown Source) Unknown.Dwb(Unknown Source) Unknown.anonymous(Unknown Source)
{noformat}

And if you try to access the {{Repository Page}} again, it keeps showing you the {{ERROR}} until you restart the Application. After that, if you enter in the {{Repository Page}} again, you will se the other repository (ABC123) normally.

!Duplicated Repo 2.jpg|thumbnail!

I tried a bunch of combinations: add the first repository (ABC-123) using the UI and the other one (ABC123) manually, the oposite too but no changes.

Thank you in advance for looking this bug.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Duplicate entries for 2 different Repositories in FishEye/Crucible UI
